images.summary: This detail illustrates the bracing and connection methods for pre-engineered roof trusses. The drawing shows how trusses are to be aligned with the studs below and toe-nailed to the top plate using (4) 3-inch nails per truss, in addition to uplift clips specified by the truss manufacturer or engineer. It details the application of 2x4 diagonal 'X' bracing on the opposite side of the truss at endwalls and other specified locations, anchored with (2) 3-1/2-inch nails at each truss. The detail also shows 2x4 struts, 5'-0" long, at the top and bottom chords, fastened with (2) 3-1/2-inch nails to each truss web member. For gable end trusses, specific fastening methods are outlined, including connections to top plates at 10" o.c. with 3-1/2-inch nails, or to through studs with (3) 3-1/2-inch nails, or to posts with (6) 4-inch nails for post walls. The "Roof Truss Bracing Notes" provide critical information for the contractor, emphasizing the need to notify the manufacturer of any truss deficiencies and detailing requirements for diagonal bracing on web members, X-bracing at endwalls, and permanent lateral bracing. Note 4 specifies that diagonal bracing is required at all discontinuities in lateral bracing, and the truss supplier shall design trusses for the bracing noted, with details not to be modified unless specified by the building designer. The detail also indicates that strapping or sheathing on the roof deck should be spaced as specified by the truss engineer, using 2x4 lumber. Blocking is shown as 2x4 lumber nailed to strapping with (5) 3-inch Ardox nails at each end, typically spaced at 8'-0" o.c. maximum. Where overhangs exceed 1'-4", a drop end truss of 5.5" is specified, along with 2x6 overhang framing cantilevered, and 2x6 ladder framing at 16" o.c. The detail highlights the importance of proper alignment and secure fastening of all bracing elements to ensure the structural integrity of the roof system.

images.summary: This section view details a typical foundation wall assembly, labeled as CW8. The foundation wall is constructed of 8-inch thick concrete, with vertical reinforcement consisting of 15M bars spaced at 48 inches on center. Horizontal reinforcement includes two 15M bars at the top of the wall and one 15M bar at grade level. The wall is anchored to a pressure-treated sill plate with 1/2-inch diameter anchor bolts spaced at 48 inches on center. The exterior of the foundation wall is shown backfilled with parent material, with a grade sloping away from the building. A minimum of 4'-0" of exterior wall is indicated above grade. Below the foundation wall is a 24-inch wide by 8-inch deep continuous concrete strip footing, reinforced with two continuous 15M bars. The footing is specified to bear on undisturbed native soil or compacted fill approved by a geotechnical engineer. The detail also shows 2" rigid insulation (R-10 minimum) extending 24" below grade, as required by code. 15M dowels, 24" long with 6" embedment, are shown connecting the foundation wall to the footing at spacing to suit the vertical rebar. A concrete slab, as per plan, is shown adjacent to the foundation wall, resting on a layer of 2" rigid insulation. Metal flashing is indicated as per client specifications.

images.summary: This section view details the connection of a pre-engineered roof truss to an embedded steel wind column, and the foundation system supporting it. The wind column, identified as a C6x8.2 channel, is shown to be embedded within a thickened concrete wall section, increasing from a standard thickness to 14 inches at the column location. The roof truss connection to the column involves a 6"x14"x1/2" steel plate secured with six 3/8" thru bolts, with a note indicating the use of carriage bolts or plate washers. The column itself is anchored to a 3'-0" x 3'-0" x 12" thick footing via a 14" x (column depth + 1/2") x 3/4" thick baseplate, which is secured with two 5/8" diameter sleeve anchors having 6" embedment. The detail also shows a 1/2" cap plate with four 1/2" diameter A325 bolts at the top of the column. Reinforcement from a continuous strip footing is shown to extend through the column footing. The drawing specifies that foundations are to bear on undisturbed native soil or compacted fill approved by a geotechnical engineer. A "TOP DETAIL" inset illustrates the connection of the C6x8.2 channel to the embedded steel wind column, showing double top plates and a 1/4" plate connection with two 1/2" diameter bolts. The slab is indicated as "SLAB PER PLAN". The section is labeled "SECTION 3 S1.0 WIND COLUMN" and is drawn at a scale of 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.element_type: Footing Schedule and Foundation Plan Notes
images.summary: This image contains a FOOTING SCHEDULE and FOUNDATION PLAN NOTES. The FOOTING SCHEDULE lists one footing type, CF1, with a size of 3'-0"x3'-0"x12" and reinforcing specified as (3) 15M B.E.W. (Bottom of Beam). Notes within the schedule indicate that all strip footings are to be 24" x 8" with (2) 15M continuous reinforcing, and all footings are to be centered on columns or walls above, unless otherwise noted (U.N.O.). The FOUNDATION PLAN NOTES provide critical information for the foundation layout and construction. Note 1 details exterior dimensions and the alignment of 2x6 and 2x8 stud walls with the foundation wall below. Note 2 explains that solid hatch patterns denote door locations and specifies a typical detail for dropping the top of the foundation wall 6" below the finished floor, continuing wall reinforcing below this drop. Note 3 clarifies that 'S.F.' denotes step footing locations and emphasizes that footings must bear on soil approved by a qualified soils inspector, with given top of footing elevations being minimum depths. Notes 4 and 5 reiterate the specifications for strip footings (24" x 8" with (2) 15M continuous reinforcing) and the centering of all footings on elements above, consistent with the footing schedule.

images.summary: This detail illustrates a foundation configuration for a wind column. It shows a 3'-0" x 3'-0" x 12" thick footing specifically designed to support the wind column, with a strip footing located below. The typical foundation wall is noted to be thickened to 14" at the wind column location, as indicated by the annotation 'THICKEN WALL TO 14" @ WIND COLUMN. (TYP.)'. The detail also references a typical foundation wall, directing the viewer to the foundation plan for specific sizing and reinforcing details. A steel beam is shown embedded within the foundation system. The approximate extent of an 8" thickened slab is also depicted, suggesting a reinforced concrete slab with localized thickening. Reinforcement is specified as 'DOUBLE 15M HAIRPINS', indicating the use of 15M rebar configured as hairpins for reinforcement. The overall depth of the foundation excavation or fill appears to be 8'-0" as indicated by a dimension line.

images.summary: This is a foundation plan view showing the layout of foundation walls and footings. The overall dimensions of the structure are indicated by various measurements such as 95'-0", 75'-0", and 256'-0". The plan details specific foundation elements labeled 'F1', 'CW8', and 'CF1', which likely correspond to footing types and wall types as defined in associated schedules or details. A note specifies that the 'DROP WALL AT DOOR LOCATIONS TO 6" BELOW FINISHED FLOOR. POUR FLOOR OVER. (TYP OF ALL OPENINGS)', indicating a specific construction detail for openings where the foundation wall is lowered and the floor is poured over it. Various dimensions like 15'-9 1/2", 18'-8", and 13'-0 1/2" denote distances between foundation elements or dimensions of specific areas. Section callouts, such as 'S1.0', are present, indicating references to other sections or details within the drawing set for further clarification of the foundation construction.

This detail illustrates the connection of a shearwall to a concrete foundation wall. The shearwall is constructed with plywood sheathing, fastened with 2-3/8" nailgun nails at 4" on center along panel edges and 12" on center in the field, as specified by the wall schedule. Solid blocking is provided at 24" on center and at all panel edges. The top of the shearwall is to be secured to a truss, as indicated by a reference to the roof plan. At each end of the shearwall, a (3)-ply stud post is present. This post is secured to an L5x3x1/4" angle, which is in turn anchored into the concrete foundation wall below with a single 5/8" diameter by 8" long hooked anchor. The (3)-ply post is attached to the angle using eight 5/16" diameter by 3" long wood lag screws. The detail also shows dimensions for the concrete foundation wall, indicating a thickness of 3" and a height of 5" for the portion shown, with 1" and 1 1/4" offsets. The scale of the drawing is 3/4" = 1'-0".

images.location: Overhead door lintel with built-up post
images.summary: This section view details an overhead door lintel assembly, incorporating a steel beam and a built-up wood post. The steel beam, the size of which is indicated to be found on the plan, supports pre-engineered roof trusses, with uplift clips specified as per the truss manufacturer's drawings. A double top plate is continuous. A 3/8" end plate connects to the steel beam, with bolt requirements specified based on beam size: W8-W10 beams use 4 x 1/2" dia. A325 thru-bolts, W12-W14 use 6 bolts, W16-W18 use 8 bolts, W21 use 10 bolts, and W24 use 12 bolts. Sub-framing below the steel beam, designed to suit typical stud size and spacing, includes continuous 2x6 or 2x8 members at the head of the opening. The framing also specifies bearing studs, full height studs, and typical stud framing as per the plan. For door hardware fastening, 2x12 members are provided at the top of the opening and 2x6 members along the sides, requiring coordination with the door manufacturer. Studs are fastened together per the CWC Wood Design Manual, with stud post to plate connections secured by two nails per stud from the bottom run of strapping. A key component is the built-up wood post, detailed to be secured to a L5x3x1/4" angle with eight 5/16" dia. x 3" lag screws. This angle is further secured with a 5/8" dia. x 8" long hooked anchor into the concrete below. The detail includes dimensions for the wood post assembly, showing a 1 1/2" width for the angle and 1 1/4" spacing for the lag screws, with a 1" typical spacing for other elements. The overall scale of the section is 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This image contains two structural schedules: a Lintel Schedule and a Column Schedule, along with notes regarding P.T. (Preservative Treated) wood ratings. The Lintel Schedule lists four lintels (L1 through L4) with their sizes and bearing details. For example, L1 is composed of (2)-2x6 lumber and requires a bearing of (1) JACK + (1) KING. L4 is a W10x26 steel beam with a "NAILER" designation, requiring a bearing of (2) JACK + (2) KING. The Column Schedule identifies one column, C1, as a W6x25 steel section, with baseplate and anchor details to be "AS PER DETAIL". Below the schedules, a section on P.T. Ratings defines various treatment levels (CSA UC1 to CSA UC4.1) based on exposure conditions, ranging from indoor, dry conditions (UC1) to outdoor wood in contact with ground or freshwater (UC4.1). A concluding note advises that members in unconditioned spaces may be left untreated, but this could affect wood condition and aesthetics over time. This information is critical for selecting appropriate materials and ensuring durability based on their intended use and environmental exposure.

images.summary: This image is an "ASSEMBLY SCHEDULE" detailing various construction assemblies. It visually presents distinct sections for "ROOF CONSTRUCTION" (R1), "EXTERIOR WALL CONSTRUCTION" (WE1), "TYPICAL SLAB ON GRADE CONSTRUCTION" (F1), and "INTERIOR PARTITION" (P1). The schedule also includes details for "SHEARWALL" and "DOUBLE SHEARWALL" construction, along with a general "NOTE" regarding blocking. The "ROOF CONSTRUCTION" specifies 29 Ga. STEEL ROOFING and roof framing as per plans, with BLOWN-IN-PLACE INSULATION rated R-40, and includes 2x4 and 1x4 strapping at 24" o.c. The "EXTERIOR WALL CONSTRUCTION" features 29 Ga. PREFIN. METAL CLADDING, 1" FOAMBOARD, TYPAR AIR BARRIER, 2x6 WOOD STUDS @ 24" o.c. with ROCKWOOL BATT INSULATION (R-22 MIN.), and 1/2" PLYWOOD SHEATHING. The "TYPICAL SLAB ON GRADE CONSTRUCTION" consists of a 5" CONCRETE FLOOR SLAB over 6 mil POLY VAPOUR BARRIER and 2" EXTRUDED POLYSTYRENE INSULATION (R10 MIN.), all on 6" COMPACTED GRANULAR 'A' FILL. The "INTERIOR PARTITION" is constructed with 2x6 STUDS @ 16" o.c. and 1/2" PLYWOOD on both sides. The "SHEARWALL" details indicate 1/2" PLYWOOD fastened with 2-3/8" NAIL-GUN NAILS at 4" o.c. on panel edges and 12" o.c. in the field, with blocking at 24" o.c. and a (3)-PLY STUD POST at each end. The "NOTE" specifies that SOLID BLOCKING is to be provided at 48" o.c. in all walls taller than 9'-6".

images.summary: This is a ground floor plan view showing the layout of structural elements. The overall dimensions indicate a large building footprint with a total length of 256'-0" and a width of 16'-0" x 8'-0" H, with other sections measuring 31'-6" and 130'-0". The plan features grid lines and various element callouts such as 'P1', 'WE1', 'L1', 'L2', 'L4', and 'C1', which likely refer to specific foundation types, wall elevations, or column types as detailed elsewhere. The dimensions along the right side of the plan show a series of 8'-4" bays, totaling 75'-0" and 95'-0", with individual bay dimensions of 10'-0" and 20'-0". There are also notations for 5'-3" x 5'-3" H elements repeated multiple times, possibly indicating column footings or specific wall sections. A section callout 'S2.1' is visible, indicating a connection to another drawing sheet for further detail. The scale is indicated as 1" = 10'-0".

This is a building section view of a proposed barn. The section illustrates the roof structure, wall assembly, and foundation system. The roof is supported by trusses, with notes indicating the need for X-bracing and lateral bracing as per the truss manufacturer's engineer. Continuous ridge venting is specified per the OBC, and eave vents are to be installed between each truss, along with prefinished metal drip edge and foam closure strips. The wall assembly includes a double top plate and is anchored to the foundation with a P.T. sill plate, sill gasket, and 1/2" diameter anchor bolts spaced at 48" on center. The foundation is a concrete foundation, with details to be shown on foundation plans, and it is specified to bear on undisturbed native soil or approved compacted fill. The section also calls out specific elements like 'WE1' for wall elevation, 'F1' for footing, and 'R1' for a ridge detail. Dimensions provided include the overall height of the truss (10'-4 1/2"), the height to the top of the foundation (2'-0"), and the height to the top of the floor (0"). Notes also specify the continuous nature of adjacent ridge and eave purlins by providing 4'-0" long 26 ga. track at splice locations with specific nail fastening. Truss uplift clips are to be installed as per truss manufacturer's drawings.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the method for creating continuous ridge (top) and eave (bottom) purlins at splice locations. The visual representation shows metal track being centered over the purlin splice. A note specifies that 2 adjacent ridge and 2 adjacent eave purlins should be made continuous by using a 4'-0" long 26 gauge metal track at each splice. This track is to be fastened with (16) 1 1/2" N10HDG (10d) nails on each side of the splice, a detail that is typical for each side of the roof. The detail also indicates that all purlin splice locations are at the center of the truss. The scale of the detail is 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This is a building section view for a storage structure, indicated by the title 'BUILDING SECTION - STORAGE' and the section callout '3/S2.1'. The view depicts the foundation, walls, and roof system. The foundation consists of concrete footings and walls, with a note stating 'CONCRETE FOUNDATIONS. SEE FOUNDATION PLANS. (TYP.)' and 'FOUNDATIONS ARE TO BEAR ON UNDISTURBED NATIVE SOIL OR COMPACTED FILL APPROVED BY GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER. (TYP.)'. The wall assembly includes a pressure-treated (P.T.) sill plate with sill gasket, secured by 1/2" diameter anchor bolts spaced at 48" on center, as indicated by the annotation 'P.T. SILL PLATE c/w SILL GASKET c/w 1/2"dia. ANCHOR BOLTS @ 48" o.c. (LEAVE OPENINGS IN SILL PLATE AT DOOR LOCATIONS) (TYP.)'. The wall itself is labeled 'WE1'. Above the wall is a double top plate. The roof structure is a wood truss system, noted as 'TRUSS (NOT AS SHOWN). SUBMIT P.ENG. STAMPED SHOP DRAWINGS FOR REVIEW.' The top of the truss is at 10'-4 1/2" above the top of the floor, and the top of the foundation is 2'-0" below the top of the floor. Continuous 2x6 X-bracing is specified to be fastened to the top side of the bottom chord of all trusses for lateral bracing, as detailed in the note 'CONTINUOUS 2x6 X-BRACING FASTENED TO TOP SIDE OF BOTTOM CHORD. INSTALL X-BRACING ON ALL TRUSSES, LATERAL BRACING AS PER TRUSS MANUF. ENGINEER (TO BE SHOWN ON PRE-ENG. TRUSS SHOP DRAWINGS)'. Truss uplift clips are also specified at each end. The roof is finished with prefinished metal fascia, eavestrough, and vented soffit, along with a metal drip edge and foam closure strip. The view indicates an 'OPEN CEILING' and includes a reference to 'CONTINUOUS RIDGE - VENTING PER OBC.' The scale of the drawing is 1/4" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This is a Roof Truss Framing Plan showing the layout and connection details for pre-engineered wood scissor roof trusses. The trusses are indicated to be designed by others and are spaced at 48 inches on center, aligning directly above studs. The plan specifies the installation of X-bracing on all trusses, with lateral bracing to be designed by the truss engineer and installed per truss shop drawings. Overlay trusses are shown at 32 inches on center in one area. Dimensions such as 96'-2 1/4", 96'-0", and 63'-11 1/4" define the overall building dimensions and bay sizes. Notes detail the requirement for attic fire stops using 1/2" OSB or 2x3 framing, ensuring continuous support for all joints and limiting compartment dimensions to 98'-4". A critical detail involves making adjacent ridge (top) and eave (bottom) purlins continuous by providing 4'-0" long 26 gauge track at each splice location. This track is to be fastened with (16) 1 1/2" N10HDG (10d) nails on each side of the splice, as referenced in Detail 1/S4.0. This detail is typical for each side of the roof, and roof vents should be avoided. Additionally, the plan specifies fastening gable end trusses to the top plate with 3-1/2" nails at 10" on center, or to each through stud with (3) 3-1/2" nails, which is typical for both gable ends. The scale of the drawing is 1" = 10'-0".
